title: Scarlett Moffatt says she directly MESSAGES trolls to check they're OK
text:
She’s no stranger to standing up for herself, recently lashing out at 'bullying' social media trolls in a scathing video in which she urged people to be kinder to one another.

And Scarlett Moffatt has revealed that she even privately messages body shamers on social media to ask if they’re okay as she discusses how she tackles negative criticism.

The former Gogglebox star 28, also stated that ‘the world would be a boring place if we all looked the same’ as she launches her new, inclusive Scarlett Loves Peacock edit.

Drastic action: Scarlett Moffatt has revealed that she even privately messages body shamers on social media to ask if they’re okay as she discusses how she tackles negative criticism

After soaring to fame on the Channel 4 show alongside her family, Scarlett has gone on to become a household name, having starred on huge shows including I’m A Celebrity, Saturday Night Takeaway and Streetmate.

But with newfound fame comes naysayers, with the County Durham native having sadly faced her fair share of internet trolls and body shamers.

And in an exclusive interview with MailOnline amid the launch of her very first fashion range, the TV personality shares the unique way in which she faces her haters head-on.

She revealed: ‘A couple of times I have inboxed people who have said horrific things and I’ve asked if they’re okay. Because I believe that hurt people, hurt people. And you’ve got to be in a really bad headspace to want to make someone feel bad.

Truth: The former Gogglebox star 28, also stated that ‘the world would be a boring place if we all looked the same’ as she launches her new, inclusive Scarlett Loves Peacock edit

‘So, a couple of times I have actually messaged people and said, “are you okay?” and every time I’ve done that, they’ve always messaged back and said, “I’m so sorry!” So hopefully they learn from it.’

Pointing out the downside to her bold actions, she added: ‘Unfortunately, you can’t spend all your time messaging people asking if they’re alright!’

It’s not just Scarlett who has her own way of coping with the criticism, her mother Betty also has a tried and tested method of releasing her anger when her daughter is trolled.

‘My mum will write out her response to the trolls but will never actually post it, she just deletes it!’ she explained. ‘She’s always like “I just want to press send!” and I’m like “you can’t! It would be everywhere; you can’t press send!”

Bold move: ‘A couple of times I have inboxed people who have said horrific things and I’ve asked if they’re okay. Because I believe that hurt people, hurt people

On a more serious note, Scarlett stresses that trolls should be called out for what they really are; ‘bullies’, adding that the word ‘troll’ in a way ‘de-humanises’ the person making them seem less real.

She explained: ‘I know that that is sounds really mean but I feel like we’ve got to a stage where the word ‘troll’… when you think of trolls you think of a fantasy character, whereas I think they should just be called bullies because that is what they are essentially.

‘I feel like by calling them trolls, we’re sort of de-humanising them and at the end of the day, they are just people being mean!’

Opening up on how the negative feedback impacts on her, she shared: ‘Obviously, it gets to me, I’d be lying if I sat here and said, “yeah everything’s fine”. But there are some days where it’s just relentless and I think I just want a bit of a break from it. But I just try and now focus on the positives,

Apology: ‘So, a couple of times I have actually messaged people and said, “are you okay?” and every time I’ve done that, they’ve always messaged back and said, “I’m so sorry!”

Speaking out: On a more serious note, Scarlett stresses that trolls should be called out for what they really are; ‘bullies’, adding that the word ‘troll’ in a way ‘de-humanises’ the person

‘I’m just in a good headspace where I think I can’t let them win. For every hundred comments, there might be five to ten bad ones. Rather than focusing on those ones, I’ll re-read the positive ones and try and focus on the positivity.’

And it’s this positivity that the presenter has held on to as she embraces her curves and conveys the message that it’s okay to just be yourself and not have to compare yourself with anyone else.

In a message of body positivity for her fans, she said: ‘Without sounding cliché, you just have to try and focus on the things you do like about yourself.

‘I think even some people even struggle to find one thing they like about themselves, but I say listen to your friends and family around you. Listen to positive things that they say, and then focus on those because sometimes we just get caught up in looking at people who are conventionally beautiful and think “why can’t I look like that?” The world would be so boring if we all looked the same!’

Having her say: 'When you think of trolls you think of a fantasy character, whereas I think they should just be called bullies because that is what they are essentially'

Amazing:' For every hundred comments, there might be five to ten bad ones. Rather than focusing on those ones, I’ll re-read the positive ones and try and focus on the positivity'

She continued: ‘There are so many people on TV that are all different shapes and sizes, it’s wonderful that some people are really fit. I’m not body shaming for those who are slim but there seems to be like a huge amount of people who are fit on the TV but not a lot of curvy girls. So, I feel like I’ve got to rep it a little bit for the curvy girls!’

And with that said, the I’m A Celebrity winner has teamed-up with Highstreet chain Peacocks to launch her new Scarlett Loves edit, which caters for women from size 8 to size 22.

Speaking of her new range, she enthused: ‘This has given me such a massive confidence boost!

Confident: Sometimes we just get caught up in looking at people who are conventionally beautiful and think “why can’t I look like that?” The world would be so boring if we all looked the same!’

‘It goes from size 8-22 and I’ve really focused on having things that nip you in the waist and cover the tops of your arms, things that I feel slightly self-conscious about. I’ve taken all those aspects away so that when you look in the mirror, you think “yeah, I look good!”.

She added: ‘The big thing that I think a lot of women struggle with, me included, is what to put with stuff. So, I tried to pick items that literally goes with jeans, with jeggings, or you can wear a dress with ankle boots and put a pair of tights on with it. I tried to choose very classic pieces. I’m really proud of it and excited for everyone to see it!’

With the recent influx of celebrity edits and endorsed clothing ranges on the market, the star revealed what makes hers stand out from the rest of the pack.

Represent: 'There seems to be like a huge amount of people who are fit on the TV but not a lot of curvy girls. So, I feel like I’ve got to rep it a little bit for the curvy girls!’

She explained: ‘Obviously aside from being affordable, I think that there isn’t a specific age. The thing is, a lot of the others are directed at young people. And with mine, yes, they can be worn by the young but because they are classic pieces, I can wear it, or my mum can wear it. I tried to not specifically go for just young people, which was hard to do, but I think we’ve really managed it!’

Further discussing the affordability of her collection, which includes a camel coat, floral print dress and chunky knits, Scarlett said: ‘Whenever I watch telly and have seen an outfit that looks amazing, I’d Google it or go on someone’s Instagram and then it turns out to be like a £400 dress!

‘Whereas a big thing for me is I wanted women and girls to be able to go “oh, where is this from?” and it will be actually affordable, and they won’t actually have to save up for a year to get it!’

Scarlett Loves Peacocks edit is out now in-store and online at www.peacocks.co.uk ranging in sizes 8-22 with prices starting from £6.00.
